hex
Class HexPlay

java.lang.Object
  online.search.commonRobot<hex.HexGameBoard>
      hex.HexPlay
All Implemented Interfaces:
HexConstants, java.lang.Runnable, online.common.PlayConstants, online.game.Play2Constants, online.game.RobotProtocol, online.game.SimpleRobotProtocol
public class HexPlay
extends commonRobot<hex.HexGameBoard>
implements java.lang.Runnable, HexConstants, online.game.RobotProtocol

the Robot player only has to implement the basic methods to generate and evaluate moves. the actual search is handled by the search driver framework.

in general, the Robot has it's own thread and operates on a copy of the board, so the main UI can continue unaffected by the processing of the robot.

Notwithstanding the "only" above, debugging robot players can be very difficult, both at the elementary level when the robot crashes out or produces obviously wrong results, or at the advanced level when the robot produces an undesirable result that is not blatantly wrong.

debugging aids:

  • List_Of_Legal_Moves() should produce only legal moves, and should by default produce all legal moves, but if your board class has some consistency checking, errors constructing the move list might be detected.
  • Turn on the "start evaluator" action, and experiment with board positions in puzzle mode. Each new position will print the current evaluation.
  • when the robot is stopped at a breakpoint (for example in Static_Evaluate_Position(online.game.commonMove) turn on the "show alternate board" option to visualize the board position. It's usually not a good idea to leave the option on when the robot is running because there will be two threads using the data simultaneously, which is not expected.
  • turn on the save_digest and check_duplicate_digest flags.
  • set commonRobot.verbose to 1 or 2. These produce relatively small amounts of output that can be helpful understanding the progress of the search
  • set a breakpoint at the exit of DoFullMove() and example the top_level_moves variable of the search driver. It contains a lot of information about the search variations that were actually examined.
  • for a small search (shallow depth, few nodes) turn on SAVE_TREE and set a breakpoint at the exit of DoFullMove()

    Author:
    ddyer

    Depth_Limit

    public boolean Depth_Limit(int current,
                           int max)
    return true if the search should be depth limited at this point. current is the current search depth, max is the maximum you set for the search. You're free to stop the search earlier or let it continue longer, but usually it's best to conduct an entire search with the same depth.

    Specified by:
    Depth_Limit in interface online.game.RobotProtocol
    Parameters:
    current - the current depth
    max - the declared maximum depth.

    Unmake_Move

    public void Unmake_Move(online.game.commonMove m)
    Called from the search driver to undo the effect of a previous Make_Move. These will always be done in reverse sequence. This is usually the most troublesome method to implement - everything else in the board manipulations moves "forward". Among other things, Unmake_Move will have to undo captures and restore captured pieces to the board, remove newly placed pieces from the board and so on.

    Among the most useful methods;

  • use the move object and the Make_Move method to store the information you will need to perform the unmove. It's also standard to restore the current player, the current move number, and the current board state from saved values rather than try to deduce the correct inverse of these state changes.
  • use stacks in the board class to keep track of changes you need to undo, and record only the index into the stack in the move object.

    Specified by:
    Unmake_Move in interface online.game.RobotProtocol

    • Make_Move

    public void Make_Move(online.game.commonMove m)
    Called from the search driver to make a move, saving information needed to unmake the move later.

    List_Of_Legal_Moves

    public online.game.CommonMoveStack List_Of_Legal_Moves()
    return a Vector of moves to consider at this point. It doesn't have to be the complete list, but that is the usual procedure. Moves in this list will be evaluated and sorted, then used as fodder for the depth limited search pruned with alpha-beta.

    Specified by:
    List_Of_Legal_Moves in interface online.game.RobotProtocol

    reScorePosition

    public double reScorePosition(online.game.commonMove m,
                              int forplayer)
    this re-evaluates the current position from the viewpoint of forplayer. for 2 player games this is to trivially negate the value, but for multiplayer games it requires considering multiple player's values.

    Specified by:
    reScorePosition in interface online.game.RobotProtocol
    Overrides:
    reScorePosition in class commonRobot<hex.HexGameBoard>

    Static_Evaluate_Position

    public double Static_Evaluate_Position(online.game.commonMove m)
    this is called from the search driver to evaluate a particular position. The driver calls List_of_Legal_Moves, then calls Make_Move/Static_Evaluate_Position/UnMake_Move for each and sorts the result to preorder the tree for further evaluation

    Specified by:
    Static_Evaluate_Position in interface online.game.RobotProtocol

    StaticEval

    public void StaticEval()
    called as a robot debugging hack from the viewer. Print debugging information about the static analysis of the current position.

    Specified by:
    StaticEval in interface online.game.SimpleRobotProtocol

    InitRobot

    public void InitRobot(online.game.ViewerProtocol newParam,
                      online.common.exHashtable info,
                      online.game.BoardProtocol gboard,
                      java.lang.String evaluator,
                      int stragegy)
    prepare the robot, but don't start making moves. G is the game object, gboard is the real game board. The real board shouldn't be changed. Evaluator and Strategy are parameters from the applet that can be interpreted as desired. The debugging menu items "set robotlevel(n)" set the value of "strategy". Evaluator is not really used at this point, but was intended to be the class name of a plugin evaluator class

    Specified by:
    InitRobot in interface online.game.SimpleRobotProtocol

    Search_Break

    public void Search_Break(java.lang.String msg)
    breakpoint or otherwise override this method to intercept search events. This is a low level way of getting control in the middle of a search for debugging purposes.

    Specified by:
    Search_Break in interface online.game.RobotProtocol

    PrepareToMove

    public void PrepareToMove(int playerIndex)
    PrepareToMove is called in the thread of the main game run loop at a point where it is appropriate to start a move. We must capture the board state at this point, so that when the robot runs it will not be affected by any subsequent changes in the real game board state. The canonical error here was the user using the < key before the robot had a chance to capture the board state.

    Specified by:
    PrepareToMove in class commonRobot<hex.HexGameBoard>

    DoAlphaBetaFullMove

    public online.game.commonMove DoAlphaBetaFullMove()

    Get_Random_Move

    public online.game.commonMove Get_Random_Move(lib.Random rand)
    get a random move by selecting a random one from the full list. For games like hex, which have trivial move generators, this is "only" a factor of 2 or so improvement in the playout rate. For games with more complex move generators, it can by much more. Diagonal-Blocks sped up by 10x

    Specified by:
    Get_Random_Move in interface online.game.RobotProtocol
    Overrides:
    Get_Random_Move in class commonRobot<hex.HexGameBoard>

    DoMonteCarloFullMove

    public online.game.commonMove DoMonteCarloFullMove()

    NormalizedScore

    public double NormalizedScore(online.game.commonMove lastMove)
    for UCT search, return the normalized value of the game, with a penalty for longer games so we try to win in as few moves as possible. Values must be normalized to -1.0 to 1.0

    Specified by:
    NormalizedScore in interface online.game.RobotProtocol
    Overrides:
    NormalizedScore in class commonRobot<hex.HexGameBoard>

    DoFullMove

    public online.game.commonMove DoFullMove()
    search for a move on behalf of player p and report the result to the game. This is called in the robot process, so the normal game UI is not encumbered by the search.

    Specified by:
    DoFullMove in class commonRobot<hex.HexGameBoard>
